awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Chicago Alliance For Equity in Computer Science (CAFECS)
awd_abstract_narration:
DePaul University, in collaboration with The Learning Partnership, Loyola University of Chicago, Chicago Public Schools (CPS), and the University of Illinois at Chicago, proposes a researcher practitioner partnership - the Chicago Alliance For Equity in Computer Science (CAFECS)- with the aim of ensuring that all CPS students have access to inclusive, high-quality, introductory computer science education in high school. CPS, the third largest school district in the nation, requires all students starting high school in Fall 2017 or later to complete a computer science (CS) course. CAFECS will ensure that CPS provides sufficient support to teachers and holds all schools accountable for offering high-quality CS across the entire district. CAFECS will empower at least 25,000 Chicago teens with the foundational practices of computer science.

CAFECS stems from a well-established partnership between university CS and educational research faculty, along with CPS teachers and administrators. The partnership began forming in Chicago a decade ago around the common goal of providing all CPS high school students access to meaningful and engaging computer science instruction. CAFECS is currently reaching a large and diverse population through the extensively-tested Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum and professional development program, with its guided-inquiry approach and a focus on engaging students through multiple modes of learning and culturally sensitive content. Over 200 teachers have completed ECS professional development delivered by CAFECS. In the 2016-2017 school year, approximately 7,000 students have completed ECS in 63 high schools (of the 106 district-run high schools). The student population in these ECS courses spans the largest population categories long underrepresented in computing includes 44% females, 38% African-American, and 47% Hispanic, which is consistent with the district-wide demographics. Building on this initial success, CPS must continue to develop mechanisms for providing professional development for teachers and principals at scale in order to ensure that all schools offer a high quality CS course to all CPS students.  The project seeks to build upon established relationships between the university partners and CPS so that they will continue to serve the community beyond the scope of the project.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The Chicago Public Schools (CPS) leads the nation in computer science education. In 2016, the Chicago Board of Education made the landmark decision to enact computer science as a graduation requirement for CPS students.  To ensure that a district supports Equitable Results in computer science, a district needs to develop Capacity for schools to offer computer science, increase Access to computer science, ensure equal Participation, and then examine how computer science Experiences lead to equitable results.

CPS had adopted the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum as the foundational course for the requirement. ECS is designed to provide all students with a robust introduction to computer science regardless of their prior computing experiences.

At the time the graduation requirement was enacted, almost half of the schools did not offer any computer science and two thirds of the schools did not have sufficient capacity to support computer science for all students. Larger schools with fewer low-income students and a strong college going climate were more likely to offer computer science just before the enactment of the graduation requirement.

The ECS professional development program supported a rapid expansion of school Capacity after the enactment of the graduation requirement. Access to computer science expanded significantly after the computer science graduation requirement. Over 250 teachers teach computer science in CPS each year. Participation in computer science significantly increased across all demographic groups after the graduation requirement. By the time the 2nd cohort graduated after the requirement, the demographics of students taking computer science matched the demographics of the district. Currently, about 19,000 CPS high school students graduate each year with at least one year of computer science. Students’ Experiences with ECS led to equivalent course performance between students taking ECS before and after the enactment of the graduation requirement.

The number of students pursuing computer science pathways in CPS doubled after the enactment of the graduation requirement. CPS students who take ECS are 3.5 times more likely to pass the AP CSA exam than equivalent students who do not take ECS first.

Intellectual Merit

The CAFÉCS research-practitioner partnership includes team members from The Learning Partnership, the Department of Computer Science (DoCS) in the Chicago Public Schools, DePaul University, Loyola University, and the University of Illinois Chicago.  The mission of the CAFÉCS RPP is to address problems of practice through research and development to ensure that all students in Chicago participate in engaging, relevant, and rigorous computing experiences, increasing opportunities for all students to pursue computing pathways and preparing all students for the future of work. Through its work on supporting the enactment of the graduation requirement policy, CAFÉCS has identified four key strategies for enabling sustainable change in school districts. These strategies have been organized into the PROSPER framework (Programs, Research, Organizational Structure, and Policy for Equivalent Results): 1) Programs: CAFÉCS impacted the selection and implementation of computer science programs, 2) Research: CAFÉCS conducted research to understand and address problems of practice facing the Office of Computer Science, 3) Organizational Structure: CAFÉCS funding impacted organizational structures in the CPS, and 4) Policy: CAFÉCS impacted the enactment and implementation of the district graduation requirement policy. The successful implementation of the graduation requirement has increased Equivalent Results in computer science education in CPS by expanding capacity, access, and participation leading to equitable experiences.

Broader Impacts

Development of a high-functioning RPP to support long-term collaboration and infrastructure development. The CAFÉCS RPP team has been engaged in work to support computer science efforts in Chicago since 2009. The consistent efforts of this strong partnership of computer science faculty, education researchers, and district personnel highlights the importance of ongoing, sustained collaboration to solve complex problems. CAFÉCS has supported the implementation of the graduation requirement and the development of CPS’ DoCS infrastructure to monitor progress and use data to make strategic decisions and developed a collaborative problem-solving cycle to address problems of practice, supporting the needs of the students and teachers in CPS.

As expected, the work accomplished through this grant has led to the development of new questions, resulting in new projects under the CAFÉCS umbrella. By advancing the full inclusion of hundreds of thousands of underrepresented students in computing education in the third largest school district, the work of CAFÉCS and DoCS has expanded the pipeline of technically informed citizens and skilled workers that will enhance the economic competitiveness of the United States.

 


Last Modified: 02/24/2025
Modified by: Lucia Dettori
